Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: A New Analyzer for In-Situ Characterization of Engineered Nanoparticles

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract
#1230189
Sadik, Omowunmi A.

Intellectual Merit
Novel environmental nanoparticle analyzers and methods are needed to assess the risks posed by engineered nanomaterials. Addressing the complex and critical issues surrounding the responsible development of nanotechnology is important both for society and the environment. The progress of society as technological advances are introduced has often resulted in the simultaneous emergence of adverse effects either for human health, the ecosystem or both. The emerging field of environmental nanotechnology is a critical research area, and one which would greatly benefit from a rapid EAGER support. Hence, the immediate goal of this research is to develop an environmentally-relevant, portable nanoparticle analyzer which can measure various levels of nanomaterials directly from pure standards, simulated matrices and real-world samples. The proposed research is expected to bridge the knowledge and methodology gaps associated with the potential environmental health and safety (EH&S) issues of nanomaterials. The resulting technology should provide information about the size or shape of the nanoparticle, which are important factors for determining toxicity; as well as distinguish them from naturally-occurring particles.

The research will make use of a new class of flexible, optically transparent conducting nanoporous membranes to simultaneously capture, isolate and detect engineered nanomaterials. Selected metal oxides and carbon based nanomaterials will be tested by integrating electrochemistry, polyamic acid membranes and tangential flow filtration to create a system that can be used in situ.

Broader Impacts
A major outcome of this project is an environmentally-relevant portable sensor system which can measure the levels of various nanomaterials directly from the environmental samples and possibly remedy them via filtration. The approach provides information regarding the size and other physical parameters of the nanomaterials, which are important in determining nanomaterials toxicity. This approach can be of great benefit for environmental and security applications because the portable analyzers can be deployed in many places to safeguard the environment, public safety, and security. This research will provide excellent training experience for graduate students as well as train undergraduate minority students who will gain exposure to field environmental analysis. Further, this research will support the enhancement of existing graduate and undergraduate courses including Chemistry and the Environment (CHEM 552C/482C) and Sensors and Bioelectronics (CHEM 424/524). Other dissemination plans include presentations at national conferences and joint publications in peer-reviewed journals in related fields.

Institution.Name: SUNY at Binghamton
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK, THE

POR.DRECONTENT:
This EAGER project targets a major challenge in environmental health and safety of nanomaterials-detection and speciation of engineered nanoparticles(ENPs). In light of the potential toxicity of ENPS, there are no technologies for on-site detection and analysis in water and in the gas phase. At present the detection of ENPs requires sophisticated instrumentation such as SEM, TEM and DLS, which are not amenable to field application.

The objective of the project was to demonstrate the concept of Electrochemical-Tangential flow filtration (EC-TFF) using nanoporous conducting polymers and electrochemical detection. The project relied on the hypothesis that the integration of electrochemistry with nanoporous conducting poly(amic) acid membrane and TFF system could create an on-site, environmental instrument that can capture, filter and detect the ENPs. We have synthesized biodegradable PAA membranes with specificity for different species of ENPs based on size, conductivity and electroactivity. Given the optical properties exhibited by the synthesized PAA membranes, some of these were also tested for fluorescent detection of selected ENPs. Examples of ENPs studied include TiO2, iron, gold, silver and nanoceria nanoparticles. The membranes were fitted onto a portable TFF device and a micro-potentiostat. This system, called EC-TFF was used to filter, detect and quantify the ENPs. PAA membranes were also fitted onto the Harvard VENGES system and the combined instrument was used for the detection of aerosolized nanoparticles.

This project could lead to the advancement of inovative technologies for drinking water, and for providing the safety of in-door facilities for gas phase nanoparticles. The project resulted in 7 peer-reviewed publications, 13 keynotes/invited/contributed presentations, one patent application and two PHD dissertations.


Last Modified: 01/30/2015
Modified by: Omowunmi A Sadik

Porosity could be controlled by the chemistry and synthetic conditions. The resulting membranes were stable, flexible and mechanically strong. C
    Sadik et al 2014, Binghamton University

    Omowunmi A Sadik
    PAA Membranes Synthesized
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This EAGER project targets a major challenge in environmental health and safety of nanomaterials-detection and speciation of engineered nanoparticles(ENPs). In light of the potential toxicity of ENPS, there are no technologies for on-site detection and analysis in water and in the gas phase. At present the detection of ENPs requires sophisticated instrumentation such as SEM, TEM and DLS, which are not amenable to field application. The objective of the project was to demonstrate the concept of Electrochemical-Tangential flow filtration (EC-TFF) using nanoporous conducting polymers and electrochemical detection. The project relied on the hypothesis that the integration of electrochemistry with nanoporous conducting poly(amic) acid membrane and TFF system could create an on-site, environmental instrument that can capture, filter and detect the ENPs. We have synthesized biodegradable PAA membranes with specificity for different species of ENPs based on size, conductivity and electroactivity. Given the optical properties exhibited by the synthesized PAA membranes, some of these were also tested for fluorescent detection of selected ENPs. Examples of ENPs studied include TiO2, iron, gold, silver and nanoceria nanoparticles. The membranes were fitted onto a portable TFF device and a micro-potentiostat. This system, called EC-TFF was used to filter, detect and quantify the ENPs. PAA membranes were also fitted onto the Harvard VENGES system and the combined instrument was used for the detection of aerosolized nanoparticles. This project could lead to the advancement of inovative technologies for drinking water, and for providing the safety of in-door facilities for gas phase nanoparticles. The project resulted in 7 peer-reviewed publications, 13 keynotes/invited/contributed presentations, one patent application and two PHD dissertations.
